summary:
Alex van Delft has a background in Engineering Physics, and a PhD in Physics/Process Control and Optimization. He joined DSM in 1989 and had several positions in Manufacturing, Engineering and (Program) Management before joining DSM Corporate Operations in 2005. He has wide experience in operations and process control improvement projects, initiated opportunity assessments and managed projects in the field. He was also program manager for the reorganization of DSM’s central engineering department. From 2005 to 2020 he was responsible for global Process Control in DSM, and as such headed a group of senior consultants. Main activities: competence management and improving the skills of the people in the competence, opportunity surveys and project support, choice of tools and suppliers, benchmarking. Between 2012 and 2014 he was also responsible for program management of the Functional Excellence activities in Operations for an important part of DSM’s business. In 2017 he was one of the initiators of the DSM Cybersecurity in Operations program. In December 2020 he co-founded VanDelft.IT as an independent consultancy company. VanDelft.IT is all about inspirational, innovative, and intelligent technology. The technology portfolio comprises knowledge and support in the areas of Process Control and Automation, Machine Learning and Data Engineering, as well as support in enhancing technological cooperation between academia/institutes and industry.

From 2010-2020 he served as Chairman of the Executive Board of WIB, the Dutch/Belgian Process Control End Users' Association.

profile_positions.description:
VanDelft.IT is all about inspirational, innovative, and intelligent technology. The technology portfolio comprises knowledge and support in the areas of Process Control and Automation, Machine Learning and Data Engineering. The leading principle is that technology is not a goal in itself, but that the benefits of technology are in its application.
Building on his experience with international cooperation, Alex van Delft is active member of the Industry Committee of IFAC, the International Federation of Automatic Control. An important milestone in March 2021 is the publication in “Control Engineering Practice” of “The impact of control research on industrial innovation: What would it take to make it happen?” co-authored jointly with Prof. Dr.  Silvia Mastellone (University of Applied Science Nordwest Switzerland). Within the context of the IFAC Industry Committee mission, in this paper a framework is proposed to close the gap between fundamental control research and industry practice.
